newsitem.title: HONG KONG: Hong Kong stocks end weak, led down by properties.
newsitem.headline: Hong Kong stocks end weak, led down by properties.

text.p: Hong Kong stocks closed on a weaker note on Wednesday, led down by losses in the property sector as a lack of incentives prevented share prices from retaining some early gains.
The Hang Seng Index shed 49.35 points to 12,766.02 after rising to a session high of 12,942.63. Turnover was HK$6.29 billion compared with HK$5.71 billion on Tuesday.

"At current levels there are not any good reasons to convince investors to buy blue chips substantially so people are just laying off a bit and seeing which direction the market will go," said Henry Lui, research analyst at Mansion House Research.
Lui said investors were divided about the future course of interest rates. The U.S. Federal Reserve decided to leave monetary policy unchanged at a meeting on Tuesday.
"I think some people expect rates to go up again in the first quarter of next year while others expect stable rates for the whole of 1997," he said.
ING Barings sales director James Osborn said while Wall Street stocks made gains overnight, "the bond market went the wrong way for equities".
The Dow rose 39.98 points to 6,308.33 on Tuesday but the U.S. long bond slipped 15/32 to yield 6.66 percent.

"Hong Kong is probably not going to wander far from the 12,800 level. There is no reason to," said Osborn. "Hong Kong has done very well this year. There is no reason for people to be window dressing in the market towards the end of the year."
In the property sector, Henderson Land fell HK$0.50 to HK$72.00 and Cheung Kong was down HK$0.50 at HK$64.00.
Hysan Development dropped HK$0.85 to HK$27.60 and Sun Hung Kai Properties slipped HK$0.25 to HK$90.75.
Satellite services provider APT Satellite Holdings made its trading debut on Wednesday and closed at HK$13.50 per share compared with an issue price of HK$13.40 per share.
Shares in Kwong Sang Hong rose HK$0.70 to HK$3.925.
Peregrine Investments Holdings said it would privatise Kwong Sang Hong, offering 200 Peregrine shares plus HK$1,700 cash for every 1,000 Kwong Sang Hong shares.
The H-share index of China-incorporated companies listed in Hong Kong fell 1.92 points to 894.87.
December Hang Seng Index futures fell 10 points to 12,820.
